Situation1: Be patient and understanding of each other's differences.
Expectation2: Respect the mentor's time and availability.
Situation2: The mentor has set aside open office hours throughout the week.
Story:
I stared at my phone, torn between two text threads. My younger brother had just messaged, frustrated after a rough day at school. He wanted to talk, and I knew he needed me to listen without judgment, to be patient and understanding—just like we’d promised each other after our last argument. At the same time, my mentor’s office hours were about to start. She’d emphasized how important it was to respect her time, to show up prepared and on schedule. I’d been looking forward to asking her about my project, and I didn’t want to waste her availability or seem uncommitted.

My brother’s words replayed in my mind, his trust in me fragile but growing. But my mentor’s calendar reminder blinked insistently, a silent expectation that I’d honor her time. I felt the pressure mounting, my heart racing as I weighed the demands. I wanted to be the sister who listened, who built respect through patience. I also wanted to be the mentee who valued her mentor’s guidance. The two roles pulled at me, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give at the same time.
